data.title: Visual Studio Code starts up unexpectedly when phone is plugged in via USB
data.body:
Visual Studio Code launches unexpectedly whenever a phone is plugged in via USB. I don't know what the one has to do with the other, but it is reproducible: When I unplug the phone and replug it in, VSC opens. I've tried multiple USB ports, multiple phones. Not sure if this happens with IOS devices, I only have Android.

- VSCode Version: 1.16.1 (commit #27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d)
- OS Version: Ubuntu 17.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install vscode
2. Plug your phone in via USB

Result: A new VSC window pops up. This also happens if the phone is plugged in while the computer starts up, meaning every time I log in, VSC pops up.

I am completely at a loss as to why this happens or why plugging a phone in and VSC opening are correlated. Maybe some mount script uses the keyword "code", but I am not sure.

data.title: VS Code window crashes
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:38:09.760Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: none
---

Steps to Reproduce:

After the application has been open for a while (days) ... I get a popup message saying the window has crashed. Has only ever done this after latest release.

data.title: Use strict version-identifier for @types/xyz-modules
data.body: This is a source of breakage. For instance, we needed to push https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/commit/81fc22ec957de26d2bf6aada3f16f04e0164741c to the `release/1.17`-branch because some d.ts files had changed so that we cannot compile anymore. For the a similar reason we are not able to compile from our `release/1.15` branch anymore. This is scary and while the underlying issue is `d-ts`-modules not caring about semver-semantics we should be acknowledging that and be strict when adding `@types/foo` dependencies.

data.title: Revert "2017-10-03. Merged in translations from Transifex."
data.body: Reverts Microsoft/vscode#35546

data.title: Git: sometimes diff stays empty when clicked
data.body:
I often end up seeing no diff when I click on a change, hard to say how to reproduce though, once I close the editor and reopen it shows up properly. Proof:

![flicker_chrome58](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/900690/31165259-b074dd9e-a8ea-11e7-9d1d-433ad6eba705.gif)

There is no output in the console when this happens.

data.title: VS Code Insiders Windows installer extremely laggy
data.body:
Couldn't find an existing issue for this, so here goes. The VS Code Insiders Windows installer is extremely laggy on my PM. Takes minutes to show the window and while the installation process itself is reasonably fast, the cleanup/restarting apps phase is similarly slow (minutes).

Is there a log I can provide? What diagnostic methods are at my disposal to identify the bottleneck for you?

data.title: any plan to use native background editor engine?
data.body:
hi,all:
i found a useful background editor engine [xieditor](https://github.com/google/xi-editor). maybe, we can use xieditor for background render,Syntax highlighting. and so on...  this is an example [xi-electron](https://github.com/callodacity/xi-electron)
it based rust language ,that means it very fast and safety.

data.title: SCM select all support.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
This change is for #22769 by providing functionality in the scmViewlet to select all when ctrl+a or cmd+a is activated.

I'm new to the project and certainly welcome any feedback on how this is implemented. In order to make sure I had the correct indexes to provide the list selection, I pull in the resources in the same manner as the list is populated. 

I added the `stopPropagation` and `preventDefault` calls to keep the editor from also selecting all the open file contents. The scm select all functionality will only trigger when the list container is focused. All other focused areas send the even to the editor.

data.title: When I Open Just One File in Initialized Git Folder - Source Control Shows Number of Changed Files

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 1703 15063.632

When I Open Just One File in Initialized Git Folder - Source Control Shows Number of Changed Files. And project folder is not shows in explorer.

It's a Bug?

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open folder with Initialized Git Repository in VSCode and make some changes in files
2. Then close VSCode
3. Open only one file from this folder in VSCode (with [right mouse button](https://i.imgur.com/3tZNbTa.png))

Gif Demonstration:

![vscode-issue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20873402/31157496-51c5b8b0-a870-11e7-85de-76d28d34bf4f.gif)

Expected Behavior:

When I open just one file in Initialized Git Folder I need to see only this file. No any information from all project (as on gif).

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Shortcuts don't respect keyboard layout
data.body:
_From @ericelliott on December 7, 2016 9:59_

I'm using the Dvorak keyboard layout.

The following shortcuts appear to be configured in the Default Keyboard Shortcuts, but don't work:

```
{ "key": "shift+cmd+=",           "command": "workbench.action.zoomIn" },
{ "key": "cmd+=",                 "command": "workbench.action.zoomIn" },
{ "key": "shift+cmd+-",           "command": "workbench.action.zoomOut" },
{ "key": "cmd+-",                 "command": "workbench.action.zoomOut" },
```

Instead, it appears to indent the current line in. When I use the physical + and - keys, it does work.


This doesn't work whether I use the physical key or the mapped key:

```
{ "key": "alt+cmd+/",             "command": "editor.action.commentLine",
                                     "when": "editorTextFocus" },
```

Note: when editing key bindings, I get little info hints that tell me to use the mapped keys (the ones that don't work) instead of the physical keys. Those info hints describe behavior that I want, but doesn't exist.

_Copied from original issue: Microsoft/vscode-sublime-keybindings#31_

data.title: XMING + Putty on Windows 10 cannot launch VSCODE
data.body:
I am running `putty` on windows 10 configured to xforward using `xming`

`$ xclock` works as expected
but if I do 
`$ code`
I get 
```[xcb] Unknown sequence number while processing queue
[xcb] Most likely this is a multi-threaded client and XInitThreads has not been called
[xcb] Aborting, sorry about that.
code: xcb_io.c:259: poll_for_event: Assertion `!xcb_xlib_threads_sequence_lost' failed.
Aborted
```
and nothing shows up.

This is different from #13438 as it is not using WSL.

data.title: Integrated terminal - links are not highlighted/clickable
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.17.0-insider
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. display some links in the integrated terminal
2. hover over with CMD pressed
3. expected - links to be underlined and clickable but they are not

In the latest Insider build no links are clickable for me - either path nor http links. I checked 1.16.1 on the same system and at least http links are clickable but paths are not either.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Feature Request: API support for autocomplete "preselection"
data.body:
The Visual Studio for Windows text editor's completion API has a feature that allows languages that implement completion to set the item that is selected when the completion list first comes up. The C# language service in VS has used this to build various experiences that they call "preselection": namely, the completion list comes up when the user types SPACE and a useful item is already selected. The canonical example of this is preselecting items after `new` in C#. `List<string>` is not normally present in the completion list, but gets specifically added preselected after the `new` keyword when the type of the expected expression is `List<string>` (or whatever).
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3751401/31152402-c0bda37e-a850-11e7-8e02-558d21622d07.png)

It would be nice if VS Code could add a similar feature (perhaps by adding a "Preselect" bit to to the CompletionItem class). If this API were available, we would definitely consume it from omnisharp-vscode.

data.title: VSCode Insiders: Integrated terminal has a LANG=en_US.UTF-8 env variable declared
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: Insiders 1.17.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set up a Windows CMD integrated terminal window
2. Launch it and inspect environment variables
3. Notice the LANG env variable? Where did that come from?

This env variable is messing with my build at work (Microsoft, Razzle). 

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

More info: Found the issue in the code:
d:\vscode-master\src\vs\workbench\parts\terminal\electron-browser\terminalInstance.ts
public static createTerminalEnv
env['LANG'] = TerminalInstance._getLangEnvVariable(locale);

More info: 
This is the issue that introduced this as a fix: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14586

Is there a way to not make it set those?

data.title: VSCode freezes when opening   7.4MB file.
data.body:
There is something specifically in this file that is causing the freeze as it doesn't seem to happen with similar sized files or without extensions. I'm guessing that it's the Lua linting.

_File listed below._

data.title: Resolve promise to fix webdriver types issue (Fixes broken build mentioned in #35543)
data.body: The typing for WebdriverIO changed several times for `keys(` causing builds to fail. This resolves the broken current build that's mentioned in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/35543.

data.title: [json] unnecessary quote-mark on code completion
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.17.0-ins
- OS Version: win7x64

If there will be no coma in the rule typed before a new one - the expansion of the new rule will add an unnecessary quote-mark in the end of it.

Strange behavior. If the algorithm wants to add something extra - **let's add that necessary coma** between the previous rule and the new one. But not an extra quote-mark, that will destroy the settings file.

![settings - unnecessary qm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24613274/31046353-977e70cc-a5ff-11e7-9ae0-1c6c9f1cfead.gif)

data.title: Shrinkwrap devDependencies
data.body:
Just a heads up, while working on #30134 I noticed that vscode does not shrinkwrap its `devDependencies`. While in npm 5 it is the default, in npm 4 it requires the extra flag `npm shrinkwrap --dev`.
This means a faulty minor/patch version somewhere in the devDependency tree (e.g. a gulp dependency etc) could cause a build failure.

As an example, master is currently broken because of a breaking change in an `@types` package: https://travis-ci.org/Microsoft/vscode/jobs/282871823#L2579

data.title: errors.reduce is not a function
data.body:
Seen when testing locally. I think TPromise.join() will always reject with the same value as the first promise that was rejected, that is not an array in general: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blame/master/src/vs/platform/extensionManagement/node/extensionManagementService.ts#L271

/Users/chrmarti/Development/repos/vscode/out/vs/workbench/services/message/browser/messageService.js:85 errors.reduce is not a function: TypeError: errors.reduce is not a function,    at ExtensionManagementService.joinErrors (file:///Users/chrmarti/Development/repos/vscode/out/vs/platform/extensionManagement/node/extensionManagementService.js:264:27),    at file:///Users/chrmarti/Development/repos/vscode/out/vs/platform/extensionManagement/node/extensionManagementService.js:255:141,    at Object.notifyError [as _notify] (file:///Users/chrmarti/Development/repos/vscode/out/vs/base/common/winjs.base.raw.js:1209:50),    at Object.enter (file:///Users/chrmarti/Development/repos/vscode/out/vs/base/common/winjs.base.raw.js:901:30),    at Promise_ctor._run (file:///Users/chrmarti/Development/repos/vscode/out/vs/base/common/winjs.base.raw.js:1068:29),    at Promise_ctor._error (file:///Users/chrmarti/Development/repos/vscode/out/vs/base/common/winjs.base.raw.js:1041:18),    at error (file:///Users/chrmarti/Development/repos/vscode/out/vs/base/common/winjs.base.raw.js:743:33),    at ErrorPromise_ctor.ErrorPromise_then [as then] (file:///Users/chrmarti/Development/repos/vscode/out/vs/base/common/winjs.base.raw.js:1436:50),    at Object.enter (file:///Users/chrmarti/Development/repos/vscode/out/vs/base/common/winjs.base.raw.js:747:28),    at Promise_ctor._run (file:///Users/chrmarti/Development/repos/vscode/out/vs/base/common/winjs.base.raw.js:1068:29)

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:38:23.027Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
project-manager|ale|0.21.1
vscode-eslint|dba|1.3.2
githistory|don|0.2.3
vscode-npm-script|eg2|0.2.1
mssql|ms-|1.2.0
debugger-for-chrome|msj|3.3.1
code-settings-sync|Sha|2.8.3
guides|spy|0.8.4

(1 theme extensions excluded - Contrast Theme)


**The following theme properties do not appear to work:**
1.  `editorSuggestWidget.highlightForeground`
2. `editorMarkerNavigationError.background`
3. `editorMarkerNavigationWarning.background`

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. [Download and install/enable Contrast Theme](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=johndugan.contrast-theme) from the vscode marketplace.
2. Open a file where the previously mentioned theme tokens should render the colors defined in the `Contrast.json` theme file.
3. Scratch head in confusion.

data.title: installed extensions pane only sized for two extensions
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.17.0-insider (5316a2d916b504cc627eb68e119e6b99ea7ad5e5, 2017-10-03T15:39:46.348Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 6.1.7601
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-eslint|dba|1.3.2
githistory|don|0.2.3
prettier-vscode|esb|0.24.0
vscode-console-wrapper|fab|0.4.0
debugger-for-chrome|msj|3.3.1
vscode-icons|rob|7.14.0



The "installed extensions" pane is only sized to show two extensions (no matter how many extensions are installed).  It can be manually resized, but upon closing vscode and reopening it will be back to a height that only displays two extensions again.  Not sure what commit changed this, but I believe it was something recent.  I would think it should default to be sized to show all installed extensions, or at least be split half and half with the "recommended extensions" pane.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Make sure vscode is completely closed
2. Open vscode, navigate to the extensions pane, and notice there are only two installed extensions visible
4. Manually resize the pane to show all installed extensions, and then close vscode
5. Re-open vscode, navigate to the extensions pane, and notice there are only two installed extensions visible again

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/430481/31139677-46cfc71e-a840-11e7-8ba7-c843b32cb00e.png)

data.body:
Feature request:

I would love to see the latest tokens of the path on my opened files if it doesn't fit the view

Take a look at this annotated image
![](https://cl.ly/1a3E3a451b2O/[4efb009c674b201ca0ff5d38e5c98770]_Image%202017-10-03%20at%201.48.28%20PM.png)

Maybe using a setting like explorer.openEditors.pathTails

data.title: Correctly get apt dirs in debian postinst
data.body:
This previously used some crazy hack to parse the output of
`apt-config dump`, instead of using `apt-config shell` like
you are supposed to do.

data.title: Confusing explanation for `activeEditorMedium` in `window.title` setting
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

The explanation for `activeEditorMedium` says
`e.g. myFolder/myFile.txt`, which made me believe that it would be the
same as `${folderName}/${activeEditorShort}`.  Instead, I saw full
paths.  After tracking it down in the code I saw the use of `contextService`:

    private get mediumTitle(): string {
        return labels.getPathLabel(this.resource, this.contextService, this.environmentService);
    }

That clarified that it's really a path that is relative to some context,
and I confirmed it by openning a file from an opened directory.

It would be better if the explanation was something like:

    path relative to root, e.g. myFolder/myFile.txt
